prior_works.title: Bringing the Web up to Speed with WebAssembly
prior_works.authors: Andreas Haas, Andreas Rossberg, Derek L. Schuff, Ben L. Titzer, et al.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Defines WebAssembly’s typed, structured control flow and implicit operand stack semantics that StackSight’s static stack-tracking and correctness constraints directly rely on.

prior_works.title: wasm-decompile (Binaryen): Decompiling WebAssembly to a readable C-like form
prior_works.authors: Alon Zakai and the Binaryen contributors
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes the feasibility of translating Wasm’s stack-based IR into readable C-like code via structural reconstruction, which StackSight advances by integrating neurosymbolic reasoning and chain-of-thought guided lifting to idiomatic C++.

prior_works.title: Soot: A Java Optimization Framework
prior_works.authors: Raja Vallée-Rai, Etienne Gagnon, Laurie Hendren, et al.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Soot’s elimination of the JVM operand stack to produce a 3-address IR (Jimple) informs StackSight’s static analysis that tracks and materializes Wasm stack effects into explicit values for subsequent decompilation.

prior_works.title: No More Gotos: Decompilation Using Structured Control Flow
prior_works.authors: Mohammed E. Yakdan, Saeed Eschweiler, Elmar Gerhards-Padilla, Matthew Smith
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides control-structure recovery techniques that underpin StackSight’s translation of Wasm’s block/loop/if constructs into structured C++ without resorting to unstructured jumps.

prior_works.title: Chain-of-Thought Prompting Elicits Reasoning in Large Language Models
prior_works.authors: Jason Wei, Xuezhi Wang, Dale Schuurmans, et al.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Directly motivates StackSight’s use of chain-of-thought prompting to guide LLMs through stepwise reasoning about stack states and control flow during decompilation.

prior_works.title: DreamCoder: Growing Libraries of Programs with Wake–Sleep Program Synthesis
prior_works.authors: Kevin Ellis, Maxwell Nye, Armando Solar-Lezama, Joshua B. Tenenbaum, et al.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrates the power of combining symbolic program reasoning with neural guidance, a paradigm StackSight adopts by coupling static analysis constraints with LLM-guided code synthesis.

prior_works.title: Evaluating Large Language Models Trained on Code (Codex)
prior_works.authors: Mark Chen, Jerry Tworek, Heewoo Jun, Qiming Yuan, et al.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Shows that LLMs can generate and translate code with high fidelity, enabling StackSight to leverage LLMs as a decompiler back-end that maps Wasm semantics to readable C++.

synthesis_narrative:
StackSight’s core innovation—neurosymbolic chain-of-thought decompilation of WebAssembly—stands on three pillars synthesized from prior work. First, the formalization of WebAssembly by Haas et al. precisely defines a typed, structured, stack-based execution model; this makes it possible to design a static analysis that soundly visualizes and tracks implicit stack effects. Classical decompilation and compiler frameworks then inform how to make that stack explicit: Soot’s stack-to-3-address lifting for JVM bytecode provides the methodological template for materializing stack values, while Yakdan et al.’s structured control-flow recovery guides the translation of Wasm’s block/loop/if constructs into idiomatic high-level code. Practical Wasm tooling, notably Binaryen’s wasm-decompile, establishes a concrete baseline for turning Wasm into readable C-like snippets, highlighting both the feasibility and limitations of purely symbolic approaches.
Second, recent advances in code-oriented LLMs (Codex) demonstrate that neural models can synthesize and translate code, making them plausible decompiler back-ends once provided with precise semantic cues. Chain-of-thought prompting operationalizes this capability, eliciting stepwise reasoning that aligns naturally with StackSight’s stack-delta traces and control annotations.
Finally, the neurosymbolic synthesis paradigm exemplified by DreamCoder motivates the coupling: symbolic program analysis constrains and scaffolds the search space, while neural reasoning proposes high-level reconstructions. StackSight integrates these threads by feeding analysis-derived stack effects and structural invariants into CoT-guided LLM prompts, yielding readable, structurally faithful C++ that outperforms prior Wasm decompilation tools.
